Page 4
Letter No. B-23-37
Morgan
A discussion of
operations necessarily involves available personnel.
In this connection I should
say that CNAC has three
Chinese pilots who have
proved their ability on seaplanes.
There are two other pilots
could be
quickly checked out on Commodores and I
am sure do a very creditable job as
the two pilots in question are the senior Chinese pilots but one in the ser-
vice of
the Company•
The No. 1 Chinese pilot,
Donald Wong, was so abused
the Chinese management that he finally
and has returned to the
United States.
For American
pilots we heve Sweet and Harry Smith, both of
whom have been flying the DC-2's and
are old experienced
airline pilots.
would have to add one more American pilot and would probably offer the position
to either Sharp or Woods who are now in Java on vacation.
Both of these pilots
have accepted
positions with Panagra but we
could withhold one of them if he
were willing to
accept an assignment with CNAC.
The Chinese communications
orgenization is
intact as is also
the motor mechanics overheul
personnel formerly stationed at Lunghwa.
Oscar Wilke,
standing by watching developments and
Chief Mechanic,
if any such plan as
that outlined in
cable 143 is worked out he
will be willing to again join CNAC.
of our oldest and best mechanics is now with CNAC and
another Americen mech-
anic Haynie,
aleo with the present Company.
With this nucleus of Amer-
ican mechanics it would be entirely praoticable to give the air planes and
proper service and maintenance.
Mr. Bond is willing to
serve
Operations Manager
and believes that with this organization he would be able
to make a creditable showing•
Eurasia is operating at a profit for the first time in its ex-
istence due to the fact that surface transportation is practically at a stan -
still.
will
However it is only a question of time in my opinion before Eurasia
to abandon its base at Hankow and probably also the
when that time
comes passengers now ca ried from Hankow to Hongkong by Eurasia
would have to travel
on the proposed CNAC line from Chungking to Hongkong; also
all international mail and a majority of domestic airmail would travel over
The present Managing Director, Lum Wei-shing is apparently desir-
ous only of bringing
the Americans back into the operations of
CNAC and then
he will be willing I believe to withdraw and join the Aviation Commission.
When I saw him in Hongkong he very carefully avoided any criticisn whatever
for me although I know
that none exists,
fact on his return to Hankow made good his promise and delivered a check to
Mr. Bond for $100,000 as he had promised he would do.
With Lum Wei-shing out
of the picture
Y. Wong in as Managing Director we should
be able to
get along much better than we ever have at any time in the past.
To sum up the whole situation the vantage of re-association are
(1) Immediate recognition by the Chinese Government of the value
of the Amer-
ican shares in CNAC as of July 31st.
(2) Extension of the contract.
Purchase of Route 3 (I suggested $300,000 U.S. in order to have a fixed sun
which would at once be recognized as materially below our actual investment
and at the same time represent an amount which I think we oan get.)
Provide for immediate payment of the balance of CNAC's account as well as
purchase of the Dolphing and the purchase of the two Commodores.
